nodes.text: Integrated assessment models that use constant elasticity of substitution (CES) to model long-term energy technology substitution produce misleading outcomes and therefore fail to represent realistic energy transitions and carbon price dynamics
CES was designed for capital-labor substitution over ranges where neither input dominates and for which substitution elasticities are approximately constant

Applying CES to technical factor inputs (e.g., substituting fossil energy with renewable energy) is a misapplication because technical substitutions can be full and the elasticity evolves during diffusion
When CES is applied to large-scale fossil-to-renewable substitution it is share-preserving and mathematically requires exponentially increasing quantities of the substitute as substitution proceeds

A stylized analytical example and Lagrangian derivation show that CES implies exponentially rising carbon prices (tax) as partial substitution proceeds, sensitive to initial shares and elasticity parameter
Historical technological and energy transitions follow S-curve (logistic, Gompertz, Bass) diffusion with dynamically changing elasticity and decreasing costs as penetration increases
Because CES is share-preserving and assumes constant elasticity, it cannot reproduce S-curve dynamics where substitution becomes easier and faster as adoption grows
The mismatch between CES behavior and observed S-curve transitions implies that CES-driven IAM results do not reflect the technical substitutability potential or realistic technology costs

Model demonstration results: with global fossil share of 85% reducing to 55% requires e.g. 13x increase in renewable input for sigma=1.5 and carbon taxes rise by orders of magnitude even for partial substitution
Transforming CES physical quantities into prices hides artifacts: exponentially increasing required renewable quantities translate into exponentially rising modeled carbon taxes
Many mainstream IAMs and hybrid models (examples: GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE, WITCH, DICE variants) implement nested CES or CES variants across production and energy sectors

Observed consequence in IAM outputs: pervasive result of monotonically or exponentially rising marginal carbon prices late-century, high carbon price knees, and reliance on incumbent technologies like CCS, nuclear, or biomass with CCS

Proposed methodological modification: use dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (decreasing rho or evolving sigma) calibrated to expected technical diffusion to better reproduce S-curve transitions within existing models

Policy implications of CES-driven artifacts: price diversion (overreliance on carbon price signals instead of physical planning), sticker shock (political resignation due to very high modeled costs), and technological myopia (overemphasis on technologies already present in model formulations)

Recommended conclusion: move toward models based on physical energy principles or at minimum incorporate dynamic elasticity and empirical diffusion behavior to generate policy-relevant, physically plausible long-term mitigation scenarios
